question_text:
You have a Fabric workspace that contains a write-intensive warehouse named DW1. DW1 stores staging tables that are used to load a dimensional model. The tables are often read once, dropped, and then recreated to process new data.

You need to minimize the load time of DW1.

What should you do?
discussion:
Option A is wrong, V-Order is enabled by default, there wouldn’t be a need to enable it again, even if not enabled, In staging scenarios like this—where tables are short-lived, often read once, and then dropped—read performance is not critical. The focus is instead on minimizing. V-Order introduces an average of 15% overhead on write times, which can negatively impact scenarios where load time is the top priority.

Option D is correct: you can avoid the write-time overhead associated with V-Order optimization, making it the most suitable choice for your requirements.

focus on minimizing load times instead of read performance

Disabling V-Order can be useful for write-intensive warehouses, such as for warehouses that are dedicated to staging data as part of a data ingestion process. Staging tables are often dropped and recreated (or truncated) to process new data. These staging tables might then be read only once or twice, which might not justify the ingestion time added by applying V-Order. By disabling V-Order and reducing the time to ingest data, your overall time to process data during ingestion jobs might be reduced.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/fabric/data-warehouse/v-order

A staging table is a temporary landing area where raw data is loaded before it’s transformed into your final dimensional model (fact/dim tables).
It’s not meant to be queried by end users.
It only exists to hold raw data temporarily, help you process it, and then be discarded.
What “read once, dropped, recreated” means
Load raw data into staging table
Example:
CREATE TABLE Staging_Sales (...);
INSERT INTO Staging_Sales VALUES (...); -- Load 1M rows
This loads data (say from CSVs, ERP, or API).
Read the staging table once
Use the data to transform & load into the dimensional model:
INSERT INTO FactSales
SELECT SaleDate, ProductID, SUM(SalesAmount)
FROM Staging_Sales
GROUP BY SaleDate, ProductID;
Here, Staging_Sales is only read once during the ETL/ELT process.
Drop the staging table
After the load is finished, you remove the staging table:
DROP TABLE Staging_Sales;

When you disable V-Order, it affects the entire warehouse (all tables inside).
in Microsoft exam questions, the canonical best practice for staging tables = drop statistics.

D is correct

option D but it affect all warehouses

Disable V-Order - This avoids the write-time overhead of applying V-Order optimization
Perfect for staging scenarios where:
Tables are short-lived
Read performance is not the priority
Load time is more important

Why wouldn't A --> Enable V-Order be the correct answer?

D is the correct answer

why is that ?

V-Order is a write time optimization, has a 15% impact on average write times, but results in an average of 10% faster read times, with some scenarios up to 50%. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/fabric/data-engineering/delta-optimization-and-v-order?tabs=sparksql
